posts.name: kuzey
posts.cooked: hi. how can i add patterns to my cad?

posts.name: Keith Farelle Cozart
posts.cooked: Like lightening patterns? Personally, I would use the “cut extrude” command and sketch out triangles to remove material. This guide is for onshape, but replace the times where they use “feature scripts” with regular solidworks sketching. david’s guide to pocketing - Google Docs . You can also check how strong your new lightened plate is by using “FEA” or finite element analysis, basically a simulation to see how your CAD will respond to various loads.

link_counts.title: david’s guide to pocketing - Google Docs

posts.name: Zach
posts.cooked: in solidworks, there’s linear and circular patterns. they’re in the features tab. you make a cut, or some sort of feature on your part, and then select that to be patterned in a circle or along a straight line depending on what you want to do. hope this helps

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
If I’m not mistaken, you may also be able to do that in a sketch as well.

(Inventor allows sketch patterns, I’m assuming SW does as well.)

posts.name: Nyx

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Everything and nothing, all at the same time

posts.custom_user_title: Everything and nothing, all at the same time

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked:
I will always advocate for feature patterns over sketch patterns for a few reasons:

They don’t clutter sketches

They are more feature rich

posts.name: Keith Farelle Cozart
posts.cooked: They also load way faster in solidworks: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F7nr8h-5sYU&t=249s
